'''Melba Joyce Montgomery''' (born October 14, 1938)<ref name="LarkinCountry">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=275}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. She is known for a series of [[duet]] recordings made with [[George Jones]], [[Gene Pitney]] and [[Charlie Louvin]]. She is also a solo artist, having reached the top of the country charts in 1974 with the song, "[[No Charge]]". Born in Tennessee but raised in Alabama, Montgomery had a musical upbringing. Along with her two brothers (songwriters Carl and Earl Montgomery), she placed in a talent contest which brought her to the attention of [[Roy Acuff]]. For several years she toured the country as part of his band until she signed with [[United Artists Records]] in 1963.

At United Artists, Montgomery collaborated with George Jones on a series of duets. Their first was 1963's "[[We Must Have Been Out of Our Minds]]", which became a top five single on the country charts. For several years, Jones and Montgomery toured and recorded together. Among their other singles was "[[What's in Our Heart (song)|What's in Our Heart]]", "[[Let's Invite Them Over]]" and "Party Pickin'". Montgomery became more identified as a duet artist as the decade progressed. She recorded with both [[Gene Pitney]] and [[Charlie Louvin]] on several charting country singles. However, her solo career was overshadowed until she moved to [[Elektra Records]] in 1973. Her 1974 song about motherhood called "No Charge" became a commercial success in several genres. It was followed by a series of charting singles, including the top 20 "[[Don't Let the Good Times Fool You (song)|Don't Let the Good Times Fool You]]" (1975).

Montgomery continued her solo career. In 1977, she reached the top 40 of the country charts again with a cover of the song, "[[Angel of the Morning]]". In the eighties, she released several recordings including the album ''I Still Care'' and the charting single "Straight Talkin'". In the nineties, Montgomery began working as a songwriter in the country music community. She wrote songs that were recorded by a series of artists. Among them was [[George Strait]], who recorded "[[What Do You Say to That]]", which became a top five country single. Montgomery has also continued sporadically releasing music as a country artist. Her most recent album was 2010's ''Things That Keep You Going'', issued on RPM Music.

==Early life==
Melba Joyce Montgomery<ref name="CM Encyclopedia">{{cite book |last1=Oermann |first1=Robert K. |title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia |date=January 4, 2012 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0199920839}}</ref> was born into a musical family in [[Iron City, Tennessee]], United States. Siblings, Carl and Earl Montgomery, later became songwriters in the country music field.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> She was raised in [[Florence, Alabama]] where her father taught vocal lessons in the local [[Methodist]] church.<ref name="Allmusic">{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=Melba Montgomery Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/melba-montgomery-mn0000868456/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2023}}</ref> Montgomery first began singing in the Methodist church<ref name="Louvin Brothers">{{cite book |last1=Wolfe |first1=Charles K. |title=In Close Harmony: The Story of the Louvin Brothers |date=1996 |publisher=[[University of Mississippi]] |isbn=978-1617034138 |page=122}}</ref> and was later given a guitar at age ten.<ref name="Allmusic"/> Montgomery and her two brothers formed a trio in their late teens. When she was age 20, the sibling trio won an amateur talent contest held at Nashville radio station WSM's Studio C, which at that time housed the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Impressed by her singing, talent content judge, [[Roy Acuff]], invited Montgomery to tour with him in replace of singer, [[June Webb]].<ref name="Allmusic"/> Montgomery toured with Acuff from 1958 until 1962.<ref name="CM Encyclopedia"/> She also briefly recorded three [[Single (music)|singles]] for the Nugget label in 1962.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>

==Career==
===1963–1972: Breakthrough with George Jones and career as a duet artist===
In 1963, Montgomery signed her first major-label recording contract with [[United Artists Records]]. Her music was discovered by [[George Jones]] (who was also on United Artists) who persuaded producer [[Pappy Daily]] to sign her to the label. The pair began recording as a duet partnership beginning in 1963.<ref name="Country">{{cite book |last1=Carlin |first1=Richard |title=Country |date=2005 |publisher=[[Infobase Publishing|Facts on File, Inc.]] |isbn=978-0816069774 |page=52}}</ref> Montgomery wrote their first duet single called "[[We Must Have Been Out of Our Minds]]".<ref name="Women">{{cite book |last1=Bufwack |first1=Mary A. |last2=Oermann |first2=Robert K. |title=''Finding Her Voice: The History of Women in Country Music'' |date=2003 |publisher=[[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt University Press]] |location=[[Nashville, Tennessee]] |isbn=978-0826514325 |pages=277–304}}</ref> In 1963, the single climbed to number three on the American ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. The song became Montgomery's breakout single.<ref name="Billboard Songs">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> It was followed by the double-sided top 20 ''Billboard'' single, "[[Let's Invite Them Over]]"/"[[What's in Our Heart (song)|What's in Our Heart]]".<ref name="Allmusic"/> The recordings were included on Jones and Montgomery's first studio album, also titled ''[[What's in Our Hearts]]''. The disc reached number three on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums|Country LP's]] list in 1963. Their second studio disc, ''[[Bluegrass Hootenanny]]'' (1964), reached number 12 on the country LP's survey.<ref name="Billboard Albums">{{cite book |last1=Whitburn |first1=Joel |title=Joel Whitburn's Top Country Albums: 1967-1997 |date=1997 |publisher=Record Research Inc. |isbn=0898201241}}</ref> Other singles by the pairing made the ''Billboard'' country top 40 through 1967: "Please Be My New Love", "Multiply the Heartaches" and "Party Pickin'".<ref name="Billboard Songs"/>
[[File:George Jones and Melba Montgomery--1960s.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Montgomery first became a commercial success as [[George Jones]]'s duet partner. In the 1960s, they recorded a series of duets such as "[[We Must Have Been Out of Our Minds]]".]]

Between 1963 and 1968, Jones and Montgomery recorded a series of duet singles and albums together. Their songs centered on themes about couples committing infidelity or comedic-themed songs about marital conflicts. The songs were then blended with Montgomery's [[Appalachian music|Appalachian]] vocal harmonies.<ref name="Women"/> Critics and writers took notice of the Jones-Montgomery duets. In reviewing a 1996 [[Compilation album|compilation]], [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[AllMusic]] found their songs to "illustrate how well-suited the pair was for each other" and that Montgomery was perhaps "Jones' best duet partner."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=''Vintage Collection Series'': George Jones & Melba Montgomery: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/vintage-collections-series-mw0000179879 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2023}}</ref> Wade Jessen of ''Billboard'' described the blending of their voices to have "electrifying intensity".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Jessen |first1=Wade |title=Duets Drive Hits |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 28, 2006 |page=50 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KQ8EAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery&pg=PA50 |access-date=2 January 2023}}</ref> The duo toured together routinely throughout the 1960s as well. "It was such an honor to get to record and work shows with him. I’ve been very very blessed through my career," Montgomery recalled.<ref name="Bluegrass Today">{{cite news |last1=Lawless |first1=John |title=''Bluegrass Hootenanny'' Remembered |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/bluegrass-hootenanny-remembered/ |access-date=2 January 2023 |work=Bluegrass Today |date=May 3, 2013}}</ref>

Montgomery also had a solo career during this period.<ref name="Allmusic"/> Her 1963 solo singles, "Hall of Shame" and "The Greatest One of All", both made the top 30 on the ''Billboard'' country songs chart.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> Her solo recordings of this era were also produced by Pappy Daily. Her debut studio album was released in 1964 by United Artists called ''America's Number One Country and Western Girl Singer''.<ref name="America's">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''America's Number One Country and Western Girl Singer'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[United Artists Records]] |date=February 1964 |id=UAS-6301}}</ref> It was followed in August 1964 by her second solo album, ''[[Down Home (Melba Montgomery album)|Down Home]]''.<ref name="Down Home">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''Down Home'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[United Artists Records]] |date=February 1964 |id=UAS-6369}}</ref> Along with [[George Jones]], Montgomery moved to [[Musicor Records]] in 1966.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Birk |first1=Carl S. |title=Unfurrowed Ground The Innovators of Country Music |date=March 2005 |publisher=Infinity Publishing |isbn=978-0741424570 |page=76}}</ref> The same year, Montgomery collaborated with [[Gene Pitney]] on the single, "[[Baby Ain't That Fine]]".<ref name="CM Encyclopedia"/> The song rose to number 15 on the ''Billboard'' country songs chart in 1966.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> A collaborative album between the pair was also released in 1966 titled ''Being Together''.<ref name="Allmusic"/>

Along with her collaborative recordings, Musicor continued releasing solo albums by Montgomery. In 1966, the label issued her first album of [[sacred music]] titled ''Hallelujah Road''.<ref name="Hallelujah Road">{{cite magazine |title=Power Packed Packages for Spring! |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=June 4, 1966 |page=34 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ASkEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+hallelujah+road+billboard&pg=PA34 |access-date=2 January 2023}}</ref> Other solo albums like ''Don't Keep Me Lonely Too Long'' (1966) contained traditional country material.<ref name="Don't Keep Me Lonely Too Long">{{cite magazine |title=Album Reviews |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 29, 1966 |page=120 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kg0EAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+dont+keep+me+lonely+too+long+billboard&pg=PT1 |access-date=2 January 2023}}</ref> However, none of her solo singles were commercially successful. Only 1967's "What Can I Tell the Folks Back Home" made the ''Billboard'' country chart, peaking at number 61.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> At [[Capitol Records]], she began being produced by [[Pete Drake]]. He was successful in pairing her as a duet partnership with [[Charlie Louvin]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Their 1970 single, "[[Something to Brag About]]", went to number 18 on the country songs chart.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> It was followed by their 1971 studio LP of the same name, which made it to number 45 on the ''Billboard'' country albums chart.<ref name="Billboard Albums"/> Five more of their duet singles made the country chart through 1972, including the top 40 entries "Did You Ever" and "[[Baby (You've Got What It Takes)|Baby You've Got What It Takes]]".<ref name="Billboard Songs"/>

===1973–1992: "No Charge" and solo career focus===
Montgomery had yet to achieve commercial success as a solo artist, despite having solo material previously released.<ref name="CM Encyclopedia"/> In 1973, producer Pete Drake helped her sign with the newly formed country division of [[Elektra Records]]. The label promised that Montgomery's music would receive promotion in the country field.<ref name="Billboard Elektra">{{cite magazine |title=Melba Montgomery |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=15 June 1974 |page=22 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZwkEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery&pg=PA16}}</ref> Her first Elektra release was 1973's "[[Wrap Your Love Around Me]]". Co-written by Montgomery, it became her third solo top 40 entry on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart and her first to reach Canada's ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' country chart.<ref name="RPM Country Songs">{{cite web|title=Search results for "Melba Montgomery" under Country Singles|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=t4coo22iqv5619fr3jv0ldfl45&q1=Melba+Montgomery&q2=Country+Singles&interval=20|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|accessdate=17 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217063904/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=t4coo22iqv5619fr3jv0ldfl45&q1=Melba+Montgomery&q2=Country+Singles&interval=20|archive-date=17 December 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="Billboard Songs"/> It was followed later in October 1973 by her [[Melba Montgomery (1973 album)|eponymous album]]. ''Billboard'' magazine named it among its "Top Album Picks" following its release.<ref name="Billboard">{{cite magazine |title=Billboard's Top Album Picks: Country |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 28, 1973 |page=64 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UwgEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+album+reviews+1973+elektra+billboard&pg=PA64 |access-date=2 January 2023}}</ref> A second single spawned from the album in early 1974 failed to reach the top 40 in the United States and Canada.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/><ref name="RPM Country Songs"/>
[[File:Melba Montgomery--1974.jpg|thumb|left|170px|A trade advertisement for Montgomery's 1974 signature recording, "[[No Charge]]".]]

In 1974, songwriter [[Harlan Howard]] brought Montgomery a song he had reportedly written especially for her called "[[No Charge]]".<ref name="UK Number Ones">{{cite book |last1=Kutner |first1=John |last2=Leigh |first2=Spencer |title=1,000 UK Number One Hits |date=2013 |publisher=[[Omnibus Press]] |isbn=978-0-85712-360-2 |page=389}}</ref> The song was written from the point of view of a mother who tells her child how she's cared for him without ever being paid for her domestic responsibilities.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Melba Montgomery, "No Charge" |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=April 20, 1974 |page=14 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQkEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery&pg=PA14 |access-date=8 January 2023}}</ref> Her performance on the song's recording reportedly made studio musicians weep while they were playing it.<ref name="CM Encyclopedia"/> The single topped the ''Billboard'' and ''RPM'' country charts around [[Mother's Day (United States)|Mother's Day]] in May 1974. It became her first (and only) number one song in her career.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/><ref name="RPM Country Songs"/> It also climbed into the top 40 of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and the ''RPM'' Top Singles chart.<ref name="Whitburn">{{cite book |last1=Whitburn |first1=Joel |title=Joel Whitburn's Billboard Top Pop Singles 1955-2006 |date=2008 |publisher=Record Research |isbn=978-0898201727}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Search results for "Melba Montgomery" under Top Singles|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=t4coo22iqv5619fr3jv0ldfl45&q1=Melba+Montgomery&q2=Top+Singles&interval=20|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> Elektra issued Montgomery's studio album of the [[No Charge (album)|same name]] in April 1974, which reached number 14 on the Top Country Albums survey.<ref name="Billboard Albums"/> The song's commercial success elevated her solo career. She appeared on both ''[[The Mike Douglas Show]]'' and ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]'' in 1974. She also played multiple venues that attracted [[Pop music|pop]] audiences. "I'm delighted 'No Charge' hit the pop charts, but we cut it as country," Montgomery reflected in 1974.<ref name="Billboard Elektra"/>

Montgomery continued releasing material with Elektra Records through the mid seventies. The follow-up singles, "Your Pretty Roses Came Too Late" and "If You Want the Rainbow", both failed to reach the country top 40 in 1974.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> Then, the up-tempo "[[Don't Let the Good Times Fool You (song)|Don't Let the Good Times Fool You]]" reached the top 15 of the country charts in 1975.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Butterfield |first1=Arthur |title=Encyclopedia of Country Music |date=1985 |publisher=[[Gallery Publishing Group|Gallery Books]] |isbn=978-0831727932 |page=159}}</ref> A studio album of the [[Don't Let the Good Times Fool You|same name]] appeared in April 1975 that reached number 47 on the Top Country Albums survey. Elektra would issue a final studio album under their label in November 1975 titled ''The Greatest Gift of All'', which failed to chart.<ref name="Billboard Albums"/><ref name="Greatest Gift of All">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''The Greatest Gift of All'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Elektra Records]] |date=November 1975 |id=CM-6}}</ref> Montgomery returned to United Artists Records in 1976 and began working under the production of [[Larry Butler (producer)|Larry Butler]].<ref>{{cite magazine |title=UA Country Artists |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 9, 1976 |page=UA-10 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ySQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+united+artists+records+billie+jo+spears&pg=PT49 |access-date=8 January 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Nelson |first1=Pat |title=Nashville Scene |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=February 12, 1977 |page=58 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S0UEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+united+artists+billboard+1977&pg=PT44 |access-date=8 January 2023}}</ref> Two of her United Artists singles made the country charts. The highest-charting was a cover of [[Merrilee Rush]]'s "[[Angel of the Morning]]", which made it to number 22 on the ''Billboard'' country chart. A more successful version would be recorded by [[Juice Newton]] in the 1980s.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> In April 1978, United Artists issued Montgomery's [[Melba Montgomery (1978 album)|second eponymous LP]] featuring "Angel of the Morning".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''Melba Montgomery'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[United Artists Records]] |date=April 1977 |id=UAS-30152}}</ref>

Montgomery went into a period of semi-retirement following her recordings with United Artists. She focused on her family and domestic responsibilities.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> She eventually returned to her recording career where she focused mostly on touring and performing.<ref name="Allmusic"/> In 1980, she returned on the Kari label with "The Star", a single which made a brief appearance on the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> In 1982, the Phonarama label released a studio album by Montgomery titled ''I Still Care''. The collection consisted of country music cover tunes.<ref name="I Still Care">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''I Still Care'' |journal=Phonorama Records |date=1982 |id=PR-5627}}</ref> A studio album of new recordings appeared on Compass Records in 1986, which was also titled ''No Charge''.<ref name="Compass Records">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''No Charge'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Compass Records]] |date=1986 |id=CO-70}}</ref> The label also issued Montgomery's last charting single to date titled "Straight Talkin'".<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> In 1992, Montgomery's next studio album was released on the Playback label titled ''Do You Know Where Your Man Is''. One year later, [[Pam Tillis]] would have a top 20 ''Billboard'' single with the album's title track.<ref name="Country Universe">{{cite web |last1=Coyne |first1=Kevin John |title=100 Greatest Women, #82: Melba Montgomery |url=https://www.countryuniverse.net/2018/04/11/100-greatest-women-82-melba-montgomery/ |website=Country Universe |date=11 April 2018 |access-date=8 January 2023}}</ref> [[AllMusic]]'s Greg Adams gave the album a two-star rating and commented, "She sounds great and the material is fine, but Do You Know Where Your Man Is isn't up to the standards of the music she made in her prime."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Adams |first1=Greg |title=''Do You Know Where Your Man Is'': Melba Montgomery: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/do-you-know-where-your-man-is-mw0000915296 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=8 January 2023}}</ref>

===1993–present: Focus on songwriting and independent album releases===
Beginning in the nineties, Montgomery started working more heavily in the field of country music songwriting.<ref>{{cite news |title=12 Surprising Country Music Hall of Fame Omissions |url=https://www.tennessean.com/picture-gallery/entertainment/music/2016/08/26/12-surprising-country-music-hall-of-fame-omissions/89357808/ |access-date=3 January 2023 |work=[[The Tennessean]] |date=August 27, 2016}}</ref> A new group of artists began recording her compositions, many of which were co-written with [[Carl Jackson]].<ref name="CM Encyclopedia"/> One of them was [[Terri Clark]], who recorded "Cure for the Common Heartache" for her 1998 album, ''[[How I Feel (album)|How I Feel]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Clark |first1=Terri |title=''How I Feel'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]] |date=May 19, 1998 |id=314-558 211-2 (Compact disc)}}</ref> She also co-wrote several songs with [[Kostas (songwriter)|Kostas]]. Among them was "You Beat All I've Ever Seen", recorded on [[Rhonda Vincent]]'s 1996 album, ''Trouble Free''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Verna |first1=Paul |title=Albums |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=March 2, 1996 |page=67 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Og8EAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+and+kostas&pg=PA67 |access-date=20 January 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vincent |first1=Rhonda |title=''Trouble Free'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]] |date=1996 |id=9 24630-2 (Compact disc)}}</ref> Montgomery has also co-wrote songs with other recording artists, such as [[Sara Evans]]. Their song, "If You Ever Want My Lovin'" was included on Evans's debut album, ''[[Three Chords and the Truth (Sara Evans album)|Three Chords and the Truth]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Alden |first1=Grant |title=Sara Evans -- ''Three Chords and the Truth'' |magazine=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]] |date=November 1, 1997 |url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/sara-evans-three-chords-and-the-truth/ |access-date=21 January 2023}}</ref> In 2000, [[George Strait]] recorded and had a top five single with "[[What Do You Say to That]]".<ref name="Billboard Songs"/> Along with its co-writer, [[Jim Lauderdale]], she was nominated for "Country Songwriter of the Year" by the [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]].<ref name="BMI">{{cite magazine |title=Awards 2000 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 14, 2000 |page=19 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBAEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+what+do+you+say+to+that&pg=PA19 |access-date=20 January 2023}}</ref> She also co-wrote the single, "Out of Control Raging Fire", which was recorded in 2001 by [[Patty Loveless]] and [[Travis Tritt]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Taylor |first1=Chuck |title=Singles |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=December 15, 2001 |page=25 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XBIEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+and+kostas&pg=PA25 |access-date=20 January 2023}}</ref>

Montgomery also continued to record her own material. In 1997, a [[Sweden|Swedish]] label released her next studio album titled ''This Time Around''. The album's ten tracks were written and co-written entirely by Montgomery. Other songwriters credited on the disc included Kostas, Jerry Salley and her husband, Jack Solomon.<ref name="This Time Around">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''This Time Around'' (Disc Information) |journal=CMC |date=1997 |id=CMCD-702}}</ref> In 1999, she joined [[John Prine]] on his studio album ''[[In Spite of Ourselves]]'' where she recorded two songs. One of them was remake of "We Must Have Been Out of Our Minds".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Morris |first1=Chris |title=Top Vocalists Join John Prine on Oh Boy! Set |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=August 28, 1999 |page=17 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nggEAAAAMBAJ&dq=melba+montgomery+this+time+around+1997&pg=PA17 |access-date=21 January 2023}}</ref> Her most recent studio album was 2010's ''Things That Keep You Going'', which was issued on RPM Music.<ref name="Things That Keep You Going">{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=Melba |title=''Things That Keep You Going'' (Disc Informartion) |journal=RPM Music |date=December 14, 2010 |id=UPC885767567504}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=''Things That Keep You Going'' |url=https://open.spotify.com/album/1spMb1muPYbJJxmVJp9hVP |website=[[Spotify]] |access-date=1 January 2023}}</ref>

==Artistry==
Montgomery's musical style is rooted in traditional country music.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Torreano |first1=Bradley |title=''Golden Moments'': Melba Montgomery: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/golden-moments-mw0000625056 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=22 January 2023}}</ref> She has also embedded elements of [[Appalachian music|Appalachian]] and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] into her musical style.<ref name="Women"/><ref name="Bluegrass Today"/> Montgomery's characteristic vocal delivery was often compared to her duet partner, George Jones, which led to her being nicknamed "the female George Jones". The pair's duet recordings were remarked as being influential on a generation of partnerships that followed in the country genre. Although Montgomery had a solo career, she is best remembered for her duets. "I guess I just couldn't get away from the duets. I believe, to a certain extent, that duets did overshadow my work as a solo artist," she recounted in 2003.<ref name="Women"/>

==Personal life==
Montgomery wed musician Jack Solomon in 1968.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=George |last2=Carter |first2=Tom |title=I Lived to Tell It All |date=June 9, 1997 |publisher=[[Random House Publishing Group]] |isbn=978-0440223733 |page=113}}</ref> Solomon first performed in George Jones's touring band called The Jones Boys and later became a session musician in Nashville. In 2014, Solomon died at the age of 71.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Nicholson |first1=Jessica |title=Lifenotes: Musician Jack L. Solomon |magazine=Music Row |date=July 1, 2014 |url=https://musicrow.com/2014/07/lifenotes-musician-jack-l-solomon/ |access-date=3 January 2023}}</ref>
